summary: This is a September 2019 report by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) reviewing the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) Brooklyn's response to a January 27, 2019 electrical fire and week-long partial power outage. The report finds the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) failed to address pre-existing heating/cooling issues, inadequately managed medical and communication issues during the outage, and did not effectively communicate with stakeholders, leading to protests, legal actions, and congressional scrutiny.

connections.description: Quay, as Warden, reported the situation to regional and central BOP management, including Hurwitz. Hurwitz supported Quay's key management decisions during the crisis.
Congresswoman Velazquez, as a stakeholder and overseer, toured the facility and interacted with Warden Quay to ascertain conditions firsthand.

Von Dornum, representing defense attorneys, was frustrated by the lack of communication from Quay's administration regarding visiting cancellations and conditions, leading to legal action against the BOP and Quay.
Congressman Nadler's public criticism of the response effort contributed to pressure on BOP leadership, including Hurwitz, and prompted high-level DOJ involvement.
Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein directed Acting BOP Director Hurwitz to take urgent action to find a needed electrical part to restore power.

events.title: Electrical Fire and Power Outage at MDC Brooklyn
events.description: An electrical fire in the West Building's mechanical room destroyed the Priority 3 switchgear, causing a partial power outage that lasted until February 3. The outage affected lighting, outlets, computers, and phones, but not heating systems.

events.title: Extreme Cold in New York City
events.description: The low temperature in New York City reached 2 degrees Fahrenheit, exacerbating pre-existing heating issues in the MDC Brooklyn West Building during the power outage.

events.title: Media Reports and Congressional Tours Begin
events.description: The New York Times published an article highlighting cold conditions and inmate distress. In response, Congresswoman Nydia Velazquez and later other members of Congress toured the facility.

events.title: Federal Court Authorizes Facility Tour
events.description: The Chief Judge of the Eastern District of New York authorized representatives from the Federal Defenders of New York and the U.S. Attorney's Office to tour the West Building to assess conditions.

events.title: BOP Issues First Press Release
events.description: Six days after the fire, the BOP issued its first press release about the situation, in response to mounting media and public pressure.

events.title: Protests Outside MDC Brooklyn
events.description: Protests occurred outside the facility, with protestors and inmates communicating. On February 3, protestors attempted to enter the building, leading staff to deploy pepper spray.

events.title: Power Restored
events.description: The electrical repair firm restored full power to the MDC Brooklyn West Building at approximately 6:30 PM.

events.title: Court Issues Temporary Restraining Order
events.description: A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order requiring MDC Brooklyn to reinstate legal visiting, citing a lack of trust in BOP representations.

events.title: OIG Initiates Review
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General initiated its review and inspection of MDC Brooklyn's handling of the fire and power outage.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) Brooklyn, West Building (houses male inmates)
Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) Brooklyn, East Building (houses female inmates)
Upper New York Bay (mentioned as a factor making certain housing units colder)
keyFacts: The power outage was caused by a fire damaging the Priority 3 electrical switchgear, but it did not affect the heating systems (Priority 1 & 2). Heating issues were due to pre-existing, long-standing temperature regulation problems in the West Building.

Temperatures in some inmate housing units fell below the BOP's winter target of 68°F before, during, and after the outage, with one recorded temperature as low as 59°F a week before the fire. The OIG could not determine the full extent due to unreliable temperature measurement methods.

MDC Brooklyn management canceled all legal and social visiting for a week due to security concerns from low lighting but failed to effectively communicate the reasons or develop timely alternative plans, severely impacting pretrial inmates' access to counsel.

The BOP and MDC Brooklyn failed to provide proactive, timely information to defense counsel, courts, families, the public, and Congress about the outage and conditions. This led to confusion, media crises, protests, multiple lawsuits, and congressional scrutiny.

The facility lacked a Building Management System (BMS) to monitor temperatures, and its contingency plans did not guide staff on communicating with external stakeholders or handling inmates dependent on electronic medical devices like CPAP machines during a power outage.
